Package uk.ac.manchester.spinnaker.spalloc

Class SpallocJob

java.lang.Object
uk.ac.manchester.spinnaker.spalloc.SpallocJob
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.AutoCloseable, SpallocJobAPI
public class SpallocJob
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.AutoCloseable, SpallocJobAPI
A high-level interface for requesting and managing allocations of SpiNNaker boards.

Constructing a SpallocJob object connects to a spalloc-server and requests a number of SpiNNaker boards. The job object may then be used to monitor the state of the request, control the boards allocated and determine their IP addresses.

In its simplest form, a SpallocJob can be used as a context manager like so: 

 try (SpallocJob j = new SpallocJob(Arrays.asList(6), null)) {
     myApplication.boot(j.getHostname(), j.getDimensions());
     myApplication.run(j.getHostname());
 }
In this example a six-board machine is requested and the try-with-resources context is entered once the allocation has been made and the allocated boards are fully powered on. When control leaves the block, the job is destroyed and the boards shut down by the server ready for another job.

For more fine-grained control, the same functionality is available via various methods: 

 SpallocJob j = new SpallocJob(Arrays.asList(6), null));
 j.waitUntilReady();
 myApplication.boot(j.getHostname(), j.getDimensions());
 myApplication.run(j.getHostname());
 j.destroy();
Note:
More complex applications may wish to log the following properties of their job to support later debugging efforts:
  • ID — May be used to query the state of the job and find out its fate if cancelled or destroyed. The spalloc-job command can be used to discover the state/fate of the job and spalloc-where-is may be used to find out what boards problem chips reside on.
  • machineName and boards together give a complete record of the hardware used by the job. The spalloc-where-is command may be used to find out the physical locations of the boards used.

  • Constructor Details

    • SpallocJob

      public SpallocJob​(java.lang.String hostname, java.lang.Integer timeout, java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> args, java.util.Map<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object> kwargs) throws java.io.IOException, SpallocServerException
      Create a spalloc job that requests a SpiNNaker machine.

      The requested machine shape can be one of the following:

      • Empty list, to get a single board.
      • Singleton list, to get a machine with that number of boards.
      • Pair, to get a rectangle of boards, width×height.
      • Triple, to get a specific board (x, y, z).
      The supported extra properties consist of:
      "owner" (String)
      The name of the owner of the job. By convention this should be your email address.
      "keepalive" (Number)
      The number of seconds after which the server may consider the job dead if this client cannot communicate with it. If null, no timeout will be used and the job will run until explicitly destroyed. Use with extreme caution.
      "machine" (String)
      Specify the name of a machine which this job must be executed on. If null, the first suitable machine available will be used, according to the tags selected below. Must be null when "tags" are given.
      "tags" (String[])
      The set of tags which any machine running this job must have. If null is supplied, only machines with the "default" tag will be used. If "machine" is given, this argument must be null.
      "min_ratio" (Double)
      The aspect ratio (h/w) which the allocated region must be 'at least as square as'. Set to 0.0 for any allowable shape, 1.0 to be exactly square etc. Ignored when allocating single boards or specific rectangles of triads.
      "max_dead_boards" (Integer)
      The maximum number of broken or unreachable boards to allow in the allocated region. If null, any number of dead boards is permitted, as long as the board on the bottom-left corner is alive.
      "max_dead_links" (Integer)
      The maximum number of broken links allow in the allocated region. When "require_torus" is true this includes wrap-around links, otherwise peripheral links are not counted. If null, any number of broken links is allowed.
      "require_torus" (Boolean)
      If true, only allocate blocks with torus connectivity. In general this will only succeed for requests to allocate an entire machine. Must be false (or not supplied) when allocating boards.
      Parameters:
      hostname - The spalloc server host
      timeout - The communications timeout
      args - The machine shape description.
      kwargs - The extra properties.
      Throws:
      java.io.IOException - If communications fail.
      SpallocServerException - If the spalloc server rejects the operation request.

    • SpallocJob

      public SpallocJob​(java.lang.String hostname, java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> args, java.util.Map<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object> kwargs) throws java.io.IOException, SpallocServerException
      Create a spalloc job that requests a SpiNNaker machine.

      The requested machine shape can be one of the following:

      • Empty list, to get a single board.
      • Singleton list, to get a machine with that number of boards.
      • Pair, to get a rectangle of boards, width×height.
      • Triple, to get a specific board (x, y, z).
      The supported extra properties consist of:
      "owner" (String)
      The name of the owner of the job. By convention this should be your email address.
      "keepalive" (Number)
      The number of seconds after which the server may consider the job dead if this client cannot communicate with it. If null, no timeout will be used and the job will run until explicitly destroyed. Use with extreme caution.
      "machine" (String)
      Specify the name of a machine which this job must be executed on. If null, the first suitable machine available will be used, according to the tags selected below. Must be null when "tags" are given.
      "tags" (String[])
      The set of tags which any machine running this job must have. If null is supplied, only machines with the "default" tag will be used. If "machine" is given, this argument must be null.
      "min_ratio" (Double)
      The aspect ratio (h/w) which the allocated region must be 'at least as square as'. Set to 0.0 for any allowable shape, 1.0 to be exactly square etc. Ignored when allocating single boards or specific rectangles of triads.
      "max_dead_boards" (Integer)
      The maximum number of broken or unreachable boards to allow in the allocated region. If null, any number of dead boards is permitted, as long as the board on the bottom-left corner is alive.
      "max_dead_links" (Integer)
      The maximum number of broken links allow in the allocated region. When "require_torus" is true this includes wrap-around links, otherwise peripheral links are not counted. If null, any number of broken links is allowed.
      "require_torus" (Boolean)
      If true, only allocate blocks with torus connectivity. In general this will only succeed for requests to allocate an entire machine. Must be false (or not supplied) when allocating boards.
      Parameters:
      hostname - The spalloc server host
      args - The machine shape description.
      kwargs - The extra properties.
      Throws:
      java.io.IOException - If communications fail.
      SpallocServerException - If the spalloc server rejects the operation request.

    • SpallocJob

      public SpallocJob​(java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> args, java.util.Map<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object> kwargs) throws java.io.IOException, SpallocServerException
      Create a spalloc job that requests a SpiNNaker machine.

      The requested machine shape can be one of the following:

      • Empty list, to get a single board.
      • Singleton list, to get a machine with that number of boards.
      • Pair, to get a rectangle of boards, width×height.
      • Triple, to get a specific board (x, y, z).

      "owner" (String)

      The number of seconds after which the server may consider the job dead if this client cannot communicate with it. If null, no timeout will be used and the job will run until explicitly destroyed. Use with extreme caution.

      Specify the name of a machine which this job must be executed on. If null, the first suitable machine available will be used, according to the tags selected below. Must be null when "tags" are given.
      "tags" (String[])
      The set of tags which any machine running this job must have. If null is supplied, only machines with the "default" tag will be used. If "machine" is given, this argument must be null.

    • SpallocJob

      public SpallocJob​(java.lang.String hostname, java.lang.Integer port, java.lang.Integer timeout, java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> args, java.util.Map<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object> kwargs) throws java.io.IOException, SpallocServerException
      Create a spalloc job that requests a SpiNNaker machine.

      The requested machine shape can be one of the following:

      • Empty list, to get a single board.
      • Singleton list, to get a machine with that number of boards.
      • Pair, to get a rectangle of boards, width×height.
      • Triple, to get a specific board (x, y, z).
      The supported extra properties consist of:
      "owner" (String)
      The name of the owner of the job. By convention this should be your email address.
      "keepalive" (Number)
      The number of seconds after which the server may consider the job dead if this client cannot communicate with it. If null, no timeout will be used and the job will run until explicitly destroyed. Use with extreme caution.
      "machine" (String)
      Specify the name of a machine which this job must be executed on. If null, the first suitable machine available will be used, according to the tags selected below. Must be null when "tags" are given.
      "tags" (String[])
      The set of tags which any machine running this job must have. If null is supplied, only machines with the "default" tag will be used. If "machine" is given, this argument must be null.
      "min_ratio" (Double)
      The aspect ratio (h/w) which the allocated region must be 'at least as square as'. Set to 0.0 for any allowable shape, 1.0 to be exactly square etc. Ignored when allocating single boards or specific rectangles of triads.
      "max_dead_boards" (Integer)
      The maximum number of broken or unreachable boards to allow in the allocated region. If null, any number of dead boards is permitted, as long as the board on the bottom-left corner is alive.
      "max_dead_links" (Integer)
      The maximum number of broken links allow in the allocated region. When "require_torus" is true this includes wrap-around links, otherwise peripheral links are not counted. If null, any number of broken links is allowed.
      "require_torus" (Boolean)
      If true, only allocate blocks with torus connectivity. In general this will only succeed for requests to allocate an entire machine. Must be false (or not supplied) when allocating boards.
      Parameters:
      hostname - The spalloc server host
      port - The spalloc server port
      timeout - The communications timeout
      args - The machine shape description.
      kwargs - The extra properties.
      Throws:
      java.io.IOException - If communications fail.
      SpallocServerException - If the spalloc server rejects the operation request.

  • Method Details

    • setConfigurationSource

      public static void setConfigurationSource​(java.lang.String filename)
      Set up where configuration settings come from. By default, this is from a file called "spalloc.ini"; this method allows you to override that (e.g., for testing).
      Parameters:
      filename - the base filename (without a path) to load the configuration from. This is expected to be a .ini file.
      See Also:
      Configuration

    • assertCompatibleVersion

      protected void assertCompatibleVersion() throws java.io.IOException, SpallocServerException
      Assert that the server version is compatible. This client supports from 0.4.0 to 2.0.0 (but not including the latter).
      Throws:
      java.io.IOException - If communications fail.
      SpallocServerException - If the spalloc server rejects the operation request.

    • setPower

      public void setPower​(java.lang.Boolean powerOn) throws java.io.IOException, SpallocServerException
      Description copied from interface: SpallocJobAPI
      Turn the boards allocated to the job on or off.

      Does nothing if the job has not yet been allocated any boards.

      The SpallocJobAPI.waitUntilReady(Integer) method may be used to wait for the boards to fully turn on or off.

      Specified by:
      setPower in interface SpallocJobAPI
      Parameters:
      powerOn - true to power on the boards, false to power off. If the boards are already turned on, setting power to true will reset them. If null, this method does nothing.
      Throws:
      java.io.IOException - If communications fail.
      SpallocServerException - If the spalloc server rejects the operation request.

      public java.lang.String getDestroyReason() throws java.io.IOException, SpallocServerException
      Specified by:
      getDestroyReason in interface SpallocJobAPI
      Returns:
      The reason for destruction of the job, or null if there is no reason (perhaps because the job isn't destroyed). Note that you should use SpallocJobAPI.getState() to determine if the job is destroyed, not this method.
      Throws:
      java.io.IOException - If communications fail.
      SpallocServerException - If the spalloc server rejects the operation request.

    • waitForStateChange

      public State waitForStateChange​(State oldState, java.lang.Integer timeout) throws SpallocServerException
      Description copied from interface: SpallocJobAPI
      Block until the job's state changes from the supplied state.
      Specified by:
      waitForStateChange in interface SpallocJobAPI
      Parameters:
      oldState - The current state.
      timeout - The number of seconds to wait for a change before timing out. If None, wait forever.
      Returns:
      The new state, or old state if timed out.
      Throws:
      SpallocServerException - If the spalloc server rejects the operation request.

    • waitUntilReady

      public void waitUntilReady​(java.lang.Integer timeout) throws JobDestroyedException, java.io.IOException, SpallocServerException, SpallocStateChangeTimeoutException
      Description copied from interface: SpallocJobAPI
      Block until the job is allocated and ready.
      Specified by:
      waitUntilReady in interface SpallocJobAPI
      Parameters:
      timeout - The number of milliseconds to wait before timing out. If None, wait forever.
      Throws:
      JobDestroyedException - If the job was destroyed before becoming ready.
      java.io.IOException - If communications fail.
      SpallocServerException - If the spalloc server rejects the operation request.
      SpallocStateChangeTimeoutException - If the timeout expired before the ready state was entered.

    • whereIs

      public BoardPhysicalCoordinates whereIs​(HasChipLocation chip) throws java.io.IOException, SpallocServerException

      Locates and returns the physical coordinates containing a given chip in a machine allocated to this job.
      Specified by:
      whereIs in interface SpallocJobAPI
      Parameters:
      chip - The coordinates of the chip
      Returns:
      the physical coordinates of the board
      Throws:
